instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: Hello. I am usually pretty good at fixing 5v issues on touchbar machines, but this one has got me stumped. This board had very minor liquid damage in some small areas around the board. It takes steady 5v on all 4 ports and the amp draw fluctuates between 40-60ma. <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> has some minor corrosion around it so I changed it but it did not make any difference. I do not find any shorts and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present at 3.4v on all 4 ports. I compared diode mode reading on all the LDO lines for the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and they all match. All 4 chips produce their 1.1v LDO rail, so it does not seem to be an issue with the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s. Despite this, I still replaced the other 3 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s just in case but still have the same issue. I figured it must be an SMC issue, so I replaced the SMC from a donor board of the same model, but still same thing. All 4 ports still steady 5v and 40-60ma. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> are both preset at 3.3v and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is ~10mv and is not shorted, so I don't know what else could be wrong. Is there something else I should check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
There should be other components affected by corrosion.
Remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.
Check ohm resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23.
Also check R/C/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: There was only some minor corrosion around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9391</CHIP>/93 and <CAPACITOR>C7608</CAPACITOR>. I removed F7000/1 and I get about 75mv on <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>. <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23 are both 3.3 ohms. I also replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> just in case, but no change. R/C/<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40 seem to all be ok. All 4 ports still takes 5v and amps cycle between 40-60ma. One thing I did notice is that when its using only 40ma, <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_4_G3H_SDA</SIGNAL> are 3.4v. Then when it goes to 60ma, both of those voltages drop to around 0.5-0.8v, then go back to 3.4v when the board goes back to 40ma current draw.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Post voltage and diode mode to ground  at <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3H_SCL</SIGNAL> /SDA lines.
Check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with battery connected; w/ and w/o charger present.
Don't forget to connect battery data cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> are both 3.3v and fluctuates down to about 2.6v every couple of seconds. Both measure 0.441 in diode mode, which matches another board I have that gets 20v. PPBUS is like 5mv with or without the battery connected and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.4v with the battery and charger, but 1.4mv with just the battery. I don't think the battery is charged though so that would be why <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing on battery alone.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
No trackpad, LCD, nor other cable connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: Yes just the board alone on the desk with charger connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Can you charge the battery with the other board, which switch to 20V?
This may help to diagnose if the problem is on USB-C side, or other side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: Yea I was able to charge the battery using another board with a dead CPU. Now when I connect this board to the charged battery and connect the charger, I get 20v 0.00a, still does not turn on. PPBUS is 12.7v and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.4v with both the battery and charger connected and its the same thing with just the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
If USB-C ports switch to 20V with battery connected, means SMC can communicate properly with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
You can have a problem with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, or its surrounding components.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 3.4v but AMON and BMON are 0v both with and without the battery connected. I replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again, but still the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL> seems low at only 0.682v. <RESISTOR>R5498</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5499</RESISTOR> are good. I have 5.2v at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5498</RESISTOR> and then 0.682v on pin 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_DCIN_VSENSE</SIGNAL>  is correct, as you don't get 20V input voltage yet.
A/BMON are also good, because the board doesn't start.

Check power on signals with charger plus battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is actually 3.4v only when just the charger is connected and the board is stuck at 5v. When the battery and charger are connected and its taking 20v, that signal is 0v. I checked the below signals with just the charger connected and then again with both charger and battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
You should get some voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, when battery is connected.
Be sure to get good contacts with data cable.
Also try another battery.
If not possible, then you have a problem with the communicayion between SMC, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: I do have 12.6v with the battery connected on PPBUS, but the board still won't start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Then check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> basic signals with battery connected.
Also check PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Check LDO and VREF rails at <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10).
Also check <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> levels.
Remember to keep battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL>    3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_PMICLDO</SIGNAL>    5.0
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL>    11.31
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_PMICVREF</SIGNAL>    1.25
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>    3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>    3.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: Both <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> are 0v. Then when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> has no reaction, but <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> goes up to 3.3v for about 3-5 seconds and then drops to 0v again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> appears at same time?
If yes, check <RESISTOR>R7810</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: No <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> does not go high at the same time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
No pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?
Then is PCH problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: Ok I started working on this again. I checked and was not getting any pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, but I had my doubts it was a PCH issue. I removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again and checked diode mode values on all the pads and compared them to a good board. I noticed pad 6 and 31 were higher than normal. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>, and the diode mode values now match my good board, but still only get 5v on the charger. I connected the battery again and still have 20v 0 amp draw. Checked for a pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> again and this time it does go to 3.3v and stays like that. <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> also goes high and I noticed the CPU was getting warm, as if the board was turning on, and CPUVCORE voltage was preset at .6v. I put the board back in the case and connected everything and when you open the lid, nothing happens, but if I hit the power button, it actually turns on and boots. Left fan is spinning at high speed, but right fan is normal. Diagnostic mode reports there may be an issue with the fan, but nothing else. If I connect the charger, it does not charge or recognize the charger on any port. I also noticed that USB devices are not recognized at all either when connected to any of the ports. The light on the USB does not even turn on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: I fixed the left fan issue. <TRANSISTOR>Q6000</TRANSISTOR> was ripped off the board and pad 2 was gone. I ran a jumper and replaced the chip and now both fans run normal. Also it does turn on when you open the lid or press the power button. Still have issues with USB ports and charging. I noticed <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> is 0v and <RESISTOR>R3038</RESISTOR> is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at L3500, or LB700?
Depending where the USB device is connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: I do not get 5v on either coil

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
So USB devices are not recognized.
Just in case, check for short at both coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: I figured it out. <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> need to be high and it was 0v. Looking over the points on the board that signal goes too, I noticed a small amount of corrosion on the pads for JB200. I cleaned the pads with new solder and now <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v and the board turns on using just the charger. I guess the corrosion there was shorting that signal somehow, even though it did not show a short. USB devices now works also on all 4 ports also. Thanks for the help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Thanks for feedback.
It will help other members for sure.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message: i also have same board no 20v boost , the 5v  not stable , amp meter show 5v and 0 , its happening repeat, same issue 2 boards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck on 5v
threads.message:
Please, open new thread with your problem.
Same symptom, doesn't imply to have the same culprit/solution.
